snippet: In bars and clubs in the East Village and on the Lower East Side, where Adam Yauch wrote some of his music, people celebrated the late rapper’s life on Friday.
abstract: People In bars and clubs in the New York's East Village and on the Lower East Side celebrate the life of late rapper and Beastie Boys founder Adam Yauch. Photo (M)
lead_paragraph: While Adam Yauch, a founder of the hip-hop group the Beastie Boys, was born in Brooklyn and rapped about the borough, it was the Lower East Side and the East Village, along with its more rough-and-tumble elements, that seemed to most inspire him. Mr. Yauch, along with Michael Diamond and Adam Horovitz, wrote raps in an apartment at 59 Chrystie Street. ''Polly Wog Stew,'' an early release, was recorded in a basement on Avenue A. And the cover of the Beastie Boys' 1989 album, ''Paul's Boutique,'' featured a ragtag clothing store at Ludlow and Rivington Streets.

headline.main: New York Neighborhoods Pay Tribute to a Beastie Boy
